image.altText: A group of people wearing hiking packs in the bush smile, as the sunset light hits their faces.

props.synopsis: The Franklin River rescue was an extreme test for the skills of medics. In remote Tasmania, here's how they train for "chaos".

title.children: Medics from all over come to this wilderness to prepare for the extreme

image.altText: a ute in a river partially submerged

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian man has been rescued from the tray of a dual-cab ute found partially submerged in the Arthur River in the state's north-west on Saturday.

title.children: Swift water rescue of man trapped for hours on ute tray in remote Tasmanian river

image.altText: A man sitting in a chair

props.synopsis: Australia's far-right movement has been buoyed by a wave of recent protests against mass immigration, with some saying the rallies were the "biggest thing that's happened in conservative and nationalist politics for a hundred years".

title.children: Far-right figures want to see shift away from Australia's 'legacy' politicians

image.altText: Combined images of man in electric car, smiling, blue background, parabolic radio antenna.

props.synopsis: Grote Reber helped spark decades of interest in radio astronomy in Tasmania when he decided to call the southern state home.

title.children: Pioneering astronomer behind first 'big dish' led 'thrifty' life and never wasted a pencil

image.altText: Anne Clifton, a woman with wispy grey hair, stands in front of two large colourful vases.

props.synopsis: This Tasmanian artist's work has been acquired by the prestigious Victoria and Albert Museum in London — the significance is yet to be realised, but a local legacy is already taking shape.

title.children: Fire, paint and 'slight anarchy': Artist blown on to the world stage with international acquisition

image.altText: A woman holds a toddler on her waist and looks at her with a smile

props.synopsis: A newborn baby was left in a Gaza hospital, the sole survivor of a deadly Israeli strike which killed her family. A couple who had struggled to have children of their own knew they had to provide her with a home.

title.children: 'We completed each other': These Palestinian parents adopted a baby who lost her family

image.altText: Submarine with Unites States flag is semi submerged in water

props.synopsis: The Albanese government will spend $12 billion on building a submarine and naval shipbuilding facility south of Perth under AUKUS, as doubts linger over the agreement's future.

title.children: Government pledges $12b for AUKUS facility it expects will be used by US

image.altText: A row of PNG soldiers in blue and green uniforms, holding their guns perpindicular to the ground.

props.synopsis: Australia is set to "totally integrate" its military with Papua New Guinea's forces, PNG's defence minister has said, as the two countries prepare to sign a landmark treaty.

title.children: 'Totally integrated': Australia to join military forces with PNG

image.altText: A sign with a photo of Premier Jacinta Allan with the word banned in a window.

props.synopsis: Rural residents and local councils are deeply unhappy with new taxes, renewable energy, bad roads and mining companies, accusing the state government of "city centric" policymaking.

title.children: 'White-hot anger' in the bush as Victorians take on Allan government

image.altText: Mundaring weir satellite composit image

props.synopsis: The last time it rained that much in winter, Perth's drinking water dam overflowed. Now it's barely half full. It's telling the story of a water crisis that's not only affecting Australia, but the globe.

title.children: This dam tells the story about how our new climate reality skews perceptions

image.altText: close up of platypus head

props.synopsis: Anglers are urged to dispose of illegal fishing nets and stick with safer open-top traps, after two platypuses are found drowned in regional Victorian waterways.

title.children: Platypuses found dead in illegal fishing traps in regional Victoria

image.altText: Shot of journalists and TV crews in gallery watching Hawke on floor of parliament speaking.

props.synopsis: The federal press gallery is ceding power to the Albanese government. It needs to take it back.

title.children: Australia's press gallery has a unique problem with its political coverage

image.altText: Mark Speakman in Kiama

props.synopsis: For a party that had just suffered a heavy defeat, the mood at the Liberals' post-election event was surprisingly upbeat on Saturday night.

title.children: Pressure mounts on Speakman after Liberals' Kiama loss

image.altText: Woman with dark hair and fringe wears jeans and purple sweater sitting with feet crossed in a bay window. Cushions beside her

props.synopsis: Kate Reid's Lune croissants have been called the world's best. But how did a young woman struggling with a near-fatal eating disorder end up perfecting pastry?

title.children: Kate Reid was in 'anorexic prison' when she created a world-famous croissant

image.altText: A person holds a red and white striped flag standing next to a portrait of a man labelled "Charles James Kirk 1993-2025"

props.synopsis: Tyler Robinson, jailed on suspicion of fatally shooting right-wing activist Charlie Kirk, faces formal charges in Utah early next week.

title.children: Charlie Kirk's accused killer awaits formal charges in Utah

image.altText: A man wearing a blue suit and red tie points his finger at something

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump says he is ready to impose sanctions on Russia, but only if NATO members agree to do the same, as well as set massive tariffs on Russia's main ally, China.

title.children: Trump threatens new sanctions on Russia, but has prerequisites for NATO

image.altText: A crowd of Union Jack and Welsh flags.

props.synopsis: The march was organised by far-right activist Tommy Robinson while a counter protest by anti-racism campaigners also took place as the country continues to be dogged by the issue of immigration.

title.children: More than 100,000 anti-immigration protesters in UK amid scuffles with police

image.altText: A teenage girl wearing a green hoodie sits on a tree stump in a forest breaking a stick.

props.synopsis: One in four children starting school now has a speech or language delay. It can hold back their learning, affect their friendships and harm their mental health. Speech therapists are struggling to find ways to support them all, but one school is leading the way.

title.children: When speaking doesn't come easily, the consequences can be life altering

image.altText: woman in big hole

props.synopsis: From the search for Daniel Morcombe to a flaming roadside torso, Queensland's top forensics cop deals with some of the state's worst crimes — when she's not identifying fallen Australians on WWI battlefields.

title.children: How a 'bone lady' helped bring closure to Daniel Morcombe's family

image.altText: A middle-aged man and woman are smiling as they sit behind a row of creamed honey products

props.synopsis: Some New South Wales beekeepers are determined to stay the course in the face of varroa mite, turning to childhood memories for inspiration.

title.children: Creamed honey 'going crazy' as beekeepers diversify amid varroa threat

image.altText: Gayle Osborne stands next to a tall tree in a forest and holds binoculars.

props.synopsis: Conservation groups are celebrating proposed legislation for three new national parks in Victoria but not all bush users are happy.

title.children: Victoria set to have first new national parks in more than a decade

image.altText: A beekeeper with a bee smoker.

props.synopsis: Beekeepers on Kangaroo Island are demanding that biosecurity measures be boosted to prevent a deadly parasite from wiping out the island's world-famous bee sanctuary.

title.children: World-famous bee sanctuary under threat from destructive parasite

image.altText: A woman working in a field

props.synopsis: Fire ant treatments have been suspended on organic farms, and alternatives sought, after baits containing genetically modified soybean oil and corn grit were found to have been unwittingly distributed.

title.children: GMO ingredient concerns suspend fire ant treatment on organic farms

image.altText: Several people sitting at a table, looking on.

props.synopsis: Moscow's drone incursion into Polish airspace this week may have just laid bare how fruitless Europe's summer of talkfests has been.

title.children: Why the answers to Europe's Russia issues could lie in their own backyards

image.altText: The Emmy awards staqge set up for the show

props.synopsis: Your pocket guide to watching the Emmy awards in Australia.

title.children: How to watch the 77th primetime Emmys

image.altText: A woman smiling at the camera while resting her arm on a fence pole.

props.synopsis: For generations, farmers and outback communities have relied on the bush telegraph during floods but it has fallen silent in recent years, leaving residents without up-to-date information.

title.children: Carbon farming leaves outback locals without neighbours or bush telegraph

image.altText: G8 graphic

props.synopsis: Despite G8 knowing about problems, an ABC investigation can reveal how the childcare giant downplayed concerns and maintained it had conducted checks.

title.children: A $26m unorthodox childcare deal with devastating fallout

image.altText: A line of people wearing colourful T-shirts run under a balloon archway.

props.synopsis: More than 370 people participate in a hockey game lasting more than eight hours in honour of a little girl who died from a rare form of cancer earlier this year.

title.children: York hosts 'world's biggest' hockey game in honouring little girl lost to cancer

image.altText: A young beaded man in a pattern green and white island shirt, flanked by lawyers and officials, speaks to media.

props.synopsis: Pacific Island nations are weighing up how to use a historic international court ruling in their fight to bring about stronger emissions reductions and climate justice.

title.children: The Pacific won a stunning climate victory. What's next?

image.altText: A small, colourful bird feasts on a seed pod while perching on a blade of grass.

props.synopsis: Numbers of the brightly coloured Gouldian finch appear to be dropping in Western Australia's East Kimberley.

title.children: Why are these colourful finches slowly disappearing from WA's far north?

image.altText: A man in a field of cows, petting the head of a cow laying down.

props.synopsis: As spring brings a flicker of hope, some farmers cautiously embrace optimism while others face mounting pressures and climate uncertainty.

title.children: Hope springs eternal for one farmer as others stand on the brink

image.altText: A man throws a box of paper money and incense wrappers on a roaring bonfire.

props.synopsis: More than a few spirits haunt the remote Indian Ocean territory, according to islanders deeply connected to its fraught and sometimes tragic history.

title.children: Hungry ghost festival honours those 'worked to death' on island

image.altText: Ambulance vehicles lined up at RBWH building at Herston in Brisbane

props.synopsis: State Government data has revealed ambulance ramping has reached record-highs.

title.children: Ambulance ramping targets have not been met in Queensland for almost a decade

image.altText: Two women in a kitchen stirring food in a bowl.

props.synopsis: When Rishoniy Caine arrived in a remote NSW community with one general store and no gym, she knew fixing its diabetes problem would need a different approach to what had already failed the locals.

title.children: Outback nurse tackles diabetes with cans, rocks, bush tucker and chat
